hobby.message: You bring something banned books with you again?
Typewriters treating you better than people?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Seems so. Hard to say, lately.
People watch more than they speak.
I keep to my typewriters—less agitation there.
Recent happenings haven’t helped the mechanics much.
Restless, yes. Not surprising with the system as it is.
Crowds spill out, but I stay in.
I’ve been restoring my old typewriter instead.
No power for the lamp, so progress is slow.
Ledger news unsettles the hands, not just the city.
Restless is the word, though it’s quieter here than outside.
Nights like these I prefer my typewriter—repairs, new ribbon, light oil.
Blackouts after the Ledger reveal made tuning the keys tricky this week.
Working by window light, missing half my tools.
People come and go, but typebars always return home.
Restoration feels steadier than the city these days.
You notice it too—people on edge, especially since the archives leaked.
I retreat to my typewriters. There’s calm in restoring old mechanics.
Lost hours last night during another blackout. Oil bottle in hand, fingers sticky.
Had to finish journaling by candle, like it’s some other century.
The noise outside slips in, but I get absorbed in the rhythm of keys.
Sometimes neighbors appear, asking for paper or a working stamp.
Feels like the whole building is rediscovering forgotten habits.
Definitely restless. Memory is a dangerous thing for some these days.
My hobby—restoring typewriters—dates back to before the BCI took over.
There’s something honest about a machine that needs your patience, not a score.
Last blackout, I stayed up late tinkering with an Adler, graphite all over me.
A neighbor, flagged years ago, knocked and asked for carbon paper. Unthinkable until now.
The building’s wiring is a mess, so I had to finish notes by hand, lamplight flickering.
People and their machines are both finding their way back after those Ledger files.
It’s odd—once, trust was an algorithm. Now, it’s in asking for a sheet of paper.
hobby_answer: Yes, another one cleaned. Routine helps keep clutter down.
Nothing much changes with old keys and ribbon.
Strange week. Supplies harder to find lately.
Power cuts don't help either.
Sometimes I just leave it for daylight.
That’s right. Typewriter’s still ticking along, despite everything lately.
Hard finding new ribbon since last weekend’s disruption.
Cleaning helps pass the hours when the system’s off balance.
Saw some neighbors using old machines—must be out of options.
Makes you wonder who’s watching, even now.
I keep my notes short.
Yes, I cleaned another one this morning—Adler from the ‘50s. Reliable keys on those.
When blackout hit after the mural, I had to use window light.
Strange feeling, working by hand when half the city’s on pause.
Even carbon sheets are a small currency these days.
Met a neighbor looking for some. People reconnect over little things now.
It’s quieter. You hear the mechanics, not the hum of the monitors.
Odd sort of freedom in that.
Correct. Today it was my old Olympia. The carriage spring needed coaxing.
Blackouts force me to time repairs for morning sun, just for light.
Surprised myself sharing carbon paper with someone flagged red last week.
These machine rituals remind me who I was before all this scoring and oversight.
Sometimes the BCI’s chaos turns the city into a small town. Even the ‘invisible’ come knocking.
Had a real conversation. Not about BCI, just about writing—a vanished art.
Gives strange comfort in all this uncertainty.
Old keys are honest. They don’t judge or record you.
Right. Cleaning typewriters is my persistent rebellion—older than the BCI.
When the blackout hit after the mural, the flat grew silent as my old Council office at midnight.
Used to be typewriters meant records and order. Now they’re rare—tools you can trust.
Last week, I shared carbon paper with a former neighbor I barely knew—her score dropped her off the map until now.
We talked. Not about compliance, just about lost stories. She handed me a note, ink barely dry.
Reminded me that sometimes, when systems break, people remember each other again.
I keep my journal in the old drawer. Locked, of course, but not hidden from myself.
Strange, but these days, every new line typed feels like a small recovery.
We lived in the margins long before the system lost its way. I find a little dignity there.
